threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
/vst/ is a place to discuss all types of strategy video games, including both turn-based and real-time strategy, turn-based and real-time tactics, single-player and multi-player (including MOBAs). All platforms are welcome.

Does this mean discussion of strategy games is banned on other video game boards? No! /vst/ is just a separate board specifically focused on strategy games where discussions about your favorite games can thrive.

Please familiarize yourself with the rules and remember to use the spoiler function where appropriate!

Please note that, like /v/, "Generals"—long-term, one-after-the-other, recurring threads about a specific game are not permitted on /vst/. Such threads belong on >>>/vg/

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>1268993
True, but it gets kind of ridiculous whenever you clearly dominated just about every major and minor battle of the Eastern theatre. There was already some dissent in the North before Lee's march about continuing the war then despite the material advantages. I highly doubt anyone would be wiling to fight it if the South regularly wrecked the North in just about every major confrontation from Bull Run to Antietam with little to no serious material or manpower losses for the southern army itself since the game doesn't really model stuff like the March to the Sea or the Confederate money printer. Then again I played on normal and I'm a contrarian try-hard, so maybe its equivalent of hard would be more fitting.

The game itself is a solid 7.5-8/10. I love the management aspects before a battle a lot. I wish Total War would take some notes from it if they ever decide to be competent and give something like Empire another go.

Went back to it because of this thread.
Didn't realise I wasted hours not actually having fun until I booted up an FPS.

Gave up because it was taking forever to dig straight down to oil (didn't want to even think about pumping water down to it in -40C conditions, closest water geyser was 2 biomes away).
>dig
>return to base
>deliver for ladder
>return to base
>build ladder
>return to base
>repeat
Almost tamed a gold volcano next to spawn. Got a turbine up however did it wrong but 40 cycles 'til dormancy to (safely) restructure the steam chamber. Glad I gave up because sorting out a radiator loop to catch the heat before it gets to my base is painful to conceive, design and even build.
Uninstalled.
>>1267801
Emergency food with simple ingredients and no skill requirements in case of the cook's untimely demise.
>wastes precious water
If someone can explain how to explore fast, or toggle creative or whatever to help you explore in a cheaty way, you should restart until you get a geyser near your spawn (water or polluted water, not slush). You will likely obtain more than you know what to do with unless you spam dupes.
Steam vents and slush geysers are just there to dilute the pool of useful geysers. They create more trouble than they're worth.

threads.com:
Why are hexfags so fucking retarded they cannot see the forest for the trees?

See picrel for why why the "diagonal movement problem" hexfags try to ascribe to squares doesn't actually exist - because you are moving in tiles, not actual distance! It doesn't matter that you have moved 1.41 feet diagonally, when you would have moved only 1 foot orthgonaly, becasue YOU ARE NOT MOVING IN REAL DISTANCE, YOU ARE MOVING IN TILES.
See picrel, it takes the exact same amount of tiles to move from one corner to the next diagonally, that it takes to move from one corner to the next orthogonally.
Yes the real distance is larger, but that does not matter, since the game is structured in tiles, not real distance!

Hexxfagging is unirinically Reddit-style thinking - believing you are some sort of expert and can overturn years of time-tested methods because you have learned some arbitrary fun fact (in this case that distance from one center of a square to the center of diagonal square is larger than the distance to the center of a orthogonal square).

TL;DR: 1 tile = 1 tile, always

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>1268382
For auxiliaries? Nope.
But for Pillars, absolutely.
The reason is due to how the Manuals are implemented:
Studying a Formation Manual has 2 effects, a global and a local one. The global ones would be "unlocking" of Nodes and Diagrams (for Ancient Formation related manuals). The local ones are a simple Modifier attached to the Cultivators, which is also how the majority of Manuals/Consumables work.
The global effect is obvious, as it grants more "building blocks" or "complete sets", so you'd only need it once. Focusing solely on that aspect, even IF you used the Nodes they grant, there's no point in learning any Formation Manual for the Pillar.
But for the local effect, have a look at the Ancient Formation wiki page (as I haven't added the related aspects to the Main page Manuals):
https://amazing-cultivation-simulator.fandom.com/wiki/Ancient_Formation#List_of_Ancient_Formations
As you can see, the "lesser" ones increase the Pillars Load by 4 each. Pretty useful if you're running a high Load Formation, or just want to decrease the Qi Cost of maintaining it. The "greater" ones on the other hand increase Load by 10, and Size by 1. Which is even better for the Pillar.
That's for the "Lv5", or Ancient Formation Manuals. Lv1-4 all have similar boosts, assigned based on the Tier of the Nodes within, so all of them are useful for boosting Size and Load for the Pillar.
The Formation Skill level also influences those two Properties, so leveling/going over the cap is still useful. If you dig into the archives, you should come across earlier posts about the Ancient Formations, with Size/Load values listed.
A smaller/lighter Layout might not benefit as much, but learning every single one will be a requirement with the higher-end of possible layouts.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>1268543
make factories that consume resources your country produces first.
build those factories in regions that produce the resource they consume for production bonuses.
you can make efficient chains of factories this way e.g. glass factories require coal, build them in a region that produces coal. liquor factories require grain and glass, build them in regions that produce grain and have a glass factory.
upgrade those factories as long as enough workers are a available until they meet the demand of their product or you don't have enough raw resources to keep them supplied at higher levels.
keep track of how much of the resource your country produces when upgrading or building a factory that produces it.

Lincoln ordered the arrest of Roger Taney, the Chief Justice of the Supreme Court after Ex Parte Merryman. Nobody would do it because Lincoln was in the wrong when he attempted to end habeas corpus and prosecute suspected traitors in military courts and he soon dropped it. They say it's a "recent controversy" but it's on the books and has been on the books since Civil War time.

The President cannot suspend habeas corpus, but that doesn't mean it doesn't happen all the time. The Ex Parte Merryman case is just one of the more blatant displays of the federal government breaking its own rules.

last_replies.com:
>>1266050
NTA, but I wouldn't actually say that. Galciv2 was fun and it made optimizing fiddly bits of math a lot more fun than stellaris does despite being decades older, but it also has some pretty obnoxious problems such as the Altarian AI bugging out and spamming invasion ships with no navy. Galciv 3 took many of the concepts in Galciv 2 and really did refine them-adjacency systems for planet development add a new dimension to economic development in a very literal way, the great person system is a big improvement on the espionage system from 2, strategic resources do a lot to improve the military system beyond "put many gun on ship, life good."

I think that Galciv 2 was better in comparison to its contemporary competition, which was basically just the already decrepit and never good MoO3 and Galaxy at War. "space 4x" has become a considerably more competitive market.

No, Jiang Wei knew the exact size and petitioned for more reinforcements which barely arrived in time due to Huang Hao trusting in magic that told him they wouldn't reach the capital, thus the invasion wasn't a worry. Jiang Wei's defensive plan had worked for the most part, but the defection of Jiang Shu, the surrender of Jiangyou and Zhuge Zhan's loss at Mianzhu were not things he could account for and all piled up. last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>1267940
>Thing that has been talked about to death in detail, no one has talked about it in detail
Longest mission timer off the top of my head in EG1 is 10 minutes, and it's one of the later ones. Every other mission in the game is between 30 seconds to four minutes and can be heavily reduced with just a few science minions. In EG2 the equivalent 'schemes' stretch way beyond any of that. EG2 merges the passive actions for the World map used to get money, with the progression/loot-gain missions from EG1. Money is teleported directly into the vault, so no one is carrying briefcases back and forth. As the devs want the game to have similar pacing to the first one(and seemingly for players to have even less control over that pacing), it means the naturally-occurring wait times of EG1 are translated into EG2 as extended timers.

Research in EG1 requires science minions to survey the base in their spare-time(they need time not doing anything else for this to happen), where they check-off a list of items as potential candidates. What you build in your base determines the possibilities. They feed these candidates into the research machine and the player chooses which to investigate and using what science equipment. The machine dispenses sample bottles which a science minion collects and uses to take samples from the object before bringing it back to the lab to use on the selected equipment. This will then succeed or fail depending on player choices and whether the minions were able to complete the jobs. This takes time, often a long time unless you have a lot of science minions, but it's long because those minions have to take an inventory object to a number of base objects and interact with them.

In EG2, it's long because it was long in EG1. The actual process itself has been removed, replaced with a time-gate: literal timers which you reduce by building blackboards or some shit.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com: Is it worthwhile to look into any EG1 mods, or is the vanilla experience still the best?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>1267993
You should at minimum get the Bonus Content. It's official content that was given for some promotion or other separately from the game, and has been distributed by fans as a mod for a long time, ever since the days of Evil Planet.
It includes a new Henchman (Colonel Blackheart), some objects for your base, and a new trap.

>Bonus Content
https://www.nexusmods.com/evilgenius/mods/16/

There's the Evil Planet Patch, which is a community-driven QoL improvement of the game from back during Evil Planet still existing.
It adds QoL features and fixes some issues with the game including potential exploits, but also changes some balance to the game by giving you way more freedom on how to build your base (allows Sentries to be built inside your base, allows all rooms to be built in both Hotel wings and underground base), and gives you a max hard cap of 150 Minions instead of the usual 100. Overall I think it's an improvement, and you can always restrain yourself from using the most game-changing parts since it does make some fixes and QoL additions that should've been in core game.

>EviL Planet Patch
https://www.nexusmods.com/evilgenius/mods/26

That's all you could possibly need, really. You could maybe want to use some retexture mod to change the coloring of your minion uniforms.
I remember spending hours on Paint editor and changing the textures of my minions to best suit my preferences, but that's entirely unnecessary and completely cosmetic.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
There's already a thread for this game. >>1241433


But to answer the question, Troubleshooter is a very slow-paced game. Early on the game sucks because you don't have enough characters to field a full team and most of the deeper mechanics are either locked behind story progression or haven't really become relevant yet. So you're stuck doing the early levels with either a small gimped team or (arguably worse) a bunch of generic police units, and some of the game's strengths like the character customization are still extremely limited.

It does slowly get better, but the keyword there is SLOWLY. You have to slog through hours worth of story missions before things start to get a more interesting. It does eventually turn into a good game IMO, especially if you're into build optimization autism and/or you get invested in the surprisingly complex story. Whether that's going to be worth it is up to you, but I can't really blame people who just ditch the game thinking it's just going to be a tedious slog all the way through.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>1264735
>Does your city break down if you gentrify too hard?
Short answer: no.
Long answer:
Residential demand is caused by job availability. All workplaces provide all classes of jobs (except high tech due to a bug, get the fix, it may not be the only bugged blackhole). You simply cannot make everyone rich or middle class even if you somehow only have CO and I-HT.
If you were to gentrify "too hard", you'd need to have multiple cities and some tax fiddling to discourage/encourage where the gentry live and where the poors do.
Your main concern is that the gentry probably won't pay for education spam on their own, but that won't necessarily matter. High education just affects manufacturing/high-tech demand unless guides and wikis are lying. All you need is land value for R$$ and R$$$ to put down roots, which elementary schools help with if you care not for parks, but I don't know what medium and high density "require" if it's not simply more land value.

Again, you may simply just struggle for tax. I've heard players complain before that I-HT doesn't pay the bills but that might just be due to a lack of job density whilst demanding better land value, service coverage and education.

There is a point in the early game before markets are unlocked (unless you just absolutely rush them) where that simply isn't sufficient to maintain a surplus of gold. I also generally don't sell my resources for money, I exhange the surplus luxury ones I have for luxuries I don't currently have, to keep my happiness up.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>1259338
Solar system colonization game. The basic goal is to develop human civilization on all the major bodies to the point of self-sufficiency. Not necessarily each body being able to function completely on its own (as not every one has enough necessary basic resources to do so), but at least not dependent upon Earth. Spans several hundred years into the future, including tech progression that is key to developing the system. For example genetic engineering being required for sustainable human habitation to allow children to grow up correctly rather than severely lacking in muscle mass, making it exponentially more difficult to go to other bodies with higher gravity. Though that's more to do with my inability to think of a good way to implement a system that can take that into account. Also things like genetically engineering plants to aid in terraforming efforts.
I want to keep it relatively hard sci-fi with things that are both possible within known physics and don't have any glaring issues with implementing them. So warp drives would not exist but NSWR or industrial antimatter use could. Terraforming would simply require smart use of resources to brute force it in the least demanding but fastest way possible, but would still take multiple lifetimes. It would also be dependent upon the specific circumstances of the body in question (so not just "spend N amount of X and Y resource to terraform this body"). For the inner Galilean moons you would have to first undergo the process of draining Jupiter's radiation belts before you could seriously inhabit or terraform them.

>>1262465
It's an awesome game.
>How does trade work?
You'll learn the game actually works off of supply and demand so building the same workshops everywhere will quickly run your economy into the ground due to upkeep and lack of profits whereas if you have a producing city and several populated cities that will realistically buy from it nearby your profits will skyrocket. Read a guide for more, there's a fair bit to it.
>How do you git gud at warfare?
To be honest, even with many armies I still mess up deploying them and end up just swarming my enemies for the most part. The battle system is weird to me and I never can get a feel for what works and what doesn't so I just take what I think is cool since numbers seem to matter more most of the time.
>Avoid peasant rebellions?
If you work the peasants for centuries they're going to want to rebel no matter what. Some people recommend giving them 10 - 30 turns to rest after 80 - 100 turns of work. To be fair, there's not really much reason you need to have peasants cutting down nearby forests after everything else has been built so this system can save you a lot of headache. The noble rebellions are a way worse threat.
